723527f.text:
Broadway, west side, south from 43rd Street, showing also a view south on Seventh Avenue. In the centre is the Pabst Hotel. Within two years this will be demolished, and the New York Times Building erected on the site.
1902.
H.N. Tiemann Co.

717492f-a.text:
Broadway, north from W. 43rd Street (intersection at right foreground) showing the open area formed by the crossing of this thoroughfare and Seventh Avenue and known as Times Square. Prominently seen is the Hotel Astor. To the left of same are brownstone structures where the 6 story Putnam Building was later erected. Today (1938) the huge Paramount Building occupies this site. Note the sole automobie and street car. To the right is the Ne York Theatre.
December 1905.
Geo. L. Balgue.

717495f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, from 43rd to 45th Streets. The Hotel Cadillac, after remodelling, will for a while be called the Wallick, but its original name will soon be restored. Rector's, a famous restaurant of the fin du sidcle days, will soon be replaced, along with the corner u ng a 4th Street, by the Hotel Claridge. In the next block, from 44th to 45th Streets, is the New York Theatre, which also houses the Criterion Theatre. This building will be torn down in 1935.
May, 1909.
Brown Brothers.

723530f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including 43rd Street, showing also the west side of Seventh Avenue, south from 43rd Street. In the centre is the second building of the New York Times, built in 1904. This building caused the name of the region bounded by Broadway and Seventh Avenue from 42nd to 47th Streets to be changed from Longacre Square to Times Square. The Times was formerly located at 41 Park Row, and in the middle 1920's will move to 43rd Street west
of Seventh Avenue.
1909.
Wurts Brothers.
:

723542f.text:
Crowds in Times Square, New York City, on election night, waiting for returns.

Nov. 1916

International Films Service

717490f.text:
1493-1505 Broadway, west side, from West 43rd (left) to 44th (right) Streets, showing the 6-story Putnam Building that today (1937) has been replaced by the mammoth Paramount Building. Shown on the left and west of a row of 4-story structures (Nos. 207 to 215 inclusive) is the 4 and 11-story Times Annex. On the right appears a corner of the Hotel Astor. This area is known as Times Square, though the buildings bear Broadway
numbers.
About 1925.
Brown Brothers.

713156f-a.text:
241-247 W:est 43rd Street, north side, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues : an old apartment house called Yandis Court.
June 1O, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

717477f-a.text:
1491-1485 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of West 43rd Street. This section of Times Square is technically Seventh Ave., with
Broadway numbers.
July 25, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

709798f-a.text:
South on Seventh Avenue, from the Paramount Theatre, at 43rd Street.
About 1929.
Photograph. by Ewing Galloway.

717487f-a.text:
The Hotel Cadillac, Broadway at the N.E. corner of 43rd Street.  Originally called by its present name, this hotel was known as the Hotel Wallace from about 1911 to about 1916.
June 28, 1933
P.L. Sperr

709800f-a.text:
Paramount Building and Theatre, Seventh Avenue, west side, from 43rd to 44th Streets, taken from 145 West 45th Street. In the right foreground may be seen the Astor Hotel, at the N.W. corner of
44th Street.
August 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

717480f-a.text:
Broadway (Times Square), at the N.E. corner of West 43rd Street, showing the Hotel Cadillac prior to demolition in 1940. At the left is the adjoining Hotel Claridge at 44th Street. In the foreground are the Police Information
Booth and a subway kiosk.
The Hotel Cadillac was erected in two units. The first to rise was the eight story corner structure. This was built as the Barrett House in 1883. The adjoining unit rose several years laterand was the first to bear the name Cadillac. In 1900 they were combined. For a brief period between 1910 and 1915 they were known as the Hotel Wallick. The land upon which they stand has been owned by the Goelet interests, passing from Ogden Goelet to his daughter May, the wife of the Duke of Roxburghe, and to her son the present Duke.
For a more complete account see the New York Times of March 19, 1940.

George L. Balgue

717488f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, north from Wost 43rd to 45th Streets, showing the 8 and 13-story units of the Hotel Claridge, the Criterion and Loew's N.Y. Theatre (under demolition), and Loew's State Theatre (N.E. corner
of 45th Street).
July 6, 1935.

723545f-a.text:
Times Square: At West 43rd Street and viewing northward. In the immediate foreground is an information booth, staffed by the New York Police Department. This set consists of two similar views.
September 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

723545f-b.text:
Times Square: At West 43rd Street and viewing northward. In the immediate foreground is an information booth, staffed by the New York Police Department. This set consists of two similar views.
September 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

723528f-a.text:
Broadway (right) and Seventh Ave. (left), north from but not including West 43rd Street, showing Times Square during a drenching afternoon rain (3 P.M.). Note the automobiles with their headlights turned on and theatres with their electric signs lighted. This view is taken from the Times Building and appeared the following day, Tuesday
July 13, 1937, in the New York Times.
July 12, 1937.
Gift of Wide World Photo Inc.

717478f-b.text:
Broadway (Times Square), at the N. E. corner of W. 43rd Street, showing the cleared site of the old Hotel Cadillac. At the left is a portion of the Hotel Claridge. W. 43rd Street is on the right and the view is eastward on the north side of same. Note the Hotel Woodstock there. It was outside of this structure that the famous
Becker murder case (Rosenthal) was enacted.
View 1: June 17, 1940
View 2: August 23, 1940
P. L. Sperr

717478f-a.text:

717494f-a.text:
Broadway (Times Square), east side, south across W. 43rd Street, showing the changes at the two corners of same. The former Hotel Cadillac site is being cleared at the N. E. corner. The two story taxpayer opposite is occupied by Toffenetti's. This was formerly the site of the Fitzgerald Building and the
George M. Cohan Theatre.
In the background are the towering buildings, No. 1450
Broadway, and the 3ush Terminal.
June 17, 1940
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
